summary:
Batman is insulted during a Justice League mission, which wouldn't be a problem except Nightwing is there to hear it. The other League members don't know this is a problem because they have no idea Batman has kids, much less that Nightwing is one of them. Bruce decides to do the only reasonable thing: go on vacation. His children probably won't burn down anything too important.

Dick just wants to defend his family and brag about his siblings. Good thing his father taught him a few things about the importance of detailed plans and talented allies.

The prank war starts with petty theft, purple, and cows.

Possible ghost kitties, a cow, a cactus, and several Bats invade the Tower. There are a few realizations had but the Bats still aren't found.

Bruce returns to the Watchtower is not surprised by what he finds. The Justice League has questions and actually gets some answers. The Batfamily definitely wins the war though.
notes:
Hello everyone! I started this story at a random point in my time travel work when I needed a bit of lightheartedness. This story has a couple family feels moments (I can't help myself)) but mainly focuses on BAMF Batfamily pranking the League. I've always loved the identity/children reveal stories and so here I go!

We have art now! Please take a look at the adorable art created by BDBriggs.

I hope you enjoy the start of the prank war and the League not yet knowing what's hitting them. There's a bit of batsibling bonding, because I cannot help myself.

One more to go! A few people are cluing in but the big reveal won't be until next chapter. Please enjoy a caring Hood and a giant cactus.

I hope you enjoyed and got some laughs out of this story! It was a little different for me but I really enjoyed writing it!
text:
Bruce was tired. 
He was tired, sore, and actually rather itchy despite the blissfully warm containment shower he had taken upon their return to the Watchtower. The mission hadn’t been difficult, exactly, but his regular human skin had not fared quite as well against the magical sparking vat of orange liquid as that of his alien and god teammates. The Batsuit could only do much. 
Nightwing, thankfully, had been in a different part of the building and hadn’t been exposed to the liquid at all. His suit had significantly less protection than the Batsuit to allow for his acrobatics and Bruce worried. 
His son also had more common sense than most of the other heroes at this table, at least from what they’d shown on this recent mission to stop a mad scientist holed up with significant ray gun technology and an entire brainwashed town. The League had rescued the town and the scientist was currently in the hands of the proper authorities, so the mission was hardly a disaster. 
It was also hardly a success.
Unfortunately, the whole team knew this and were attempting to debrief. Bruce had tried to share what he considered the top three issues and had been simply talked over, which wasn’t a usual problem. Batman was generally listened to when he spoke. Part of that reason, however, was the fact that Batman choose his moment to speak carefully and Bruce could recognize that this wasn’t a good moment. Everyone was too overly energetic and there wasn’t an incoming threat or mission to use as a focus.
Besides, it would hardly do his reputation good to be talked over again.
Nightwing was providing a more enjoyable alternative than attempting to corral the masses with his scathing commentary over various hand signals and slight facial expressions. Bruce would be insulted by some of Dick’s comparisons of the Justice League to the Titans (and on at least two occasions Damian’s dog, Titus), except at this moment Bruce rather agreed with him. 
He wondered how much longer until Dick faked a Titans’s emergency and ducked out of the meeting, since the ability to prioritize his own team had been one of the agreements struck when Flash had recruited Nightwing. The Justice League had been more than willing to accept a few conditions for a hero of Nightwing’s reputation, not to mention the several Titans that even Hal could tell only joined to support their leader.
Bruce had been so proud the day Nightwing had been sworn in, Cyborg and Raven flanking him for the entire ceremony. It was perhaps a bit bittersweet, since Bruce knew the moment signalled the end of almost all his arguments for keeping his kids a secret. Oh, the Justice League knew there were additional vigilantes in Gotham but the secretive nature of the Bats and Gotham itself had allowed Bruce to keep information to a minimum with a few judiciously applied glares. 
Bruce understood Gotham and, while he knew and completely believed in the importance of the Justice League, it was easier to keep his children safe in Gotham. To believe they were safer outside of their city when they couldn’t be linked back to Batman and used against each other. When not even the heroes knew that any of his children had an entire support network that was completely unseen and only a call away. 
But he trusted the Justice League now, today’s mess notwithstanding, and his children knew it. Knew that Bruce would never have let Dick join (have backed his joining in full view and support of Flash’s nomination) if the League wasn’t trustworthy. His children were humouring Bruce, now, and only because they could see that Bruce himself knew the time was approaching to reveal their secret identities to their friends. 
Besides, the no civilian names thing had been leveraged with impressive cohesion and teamwork to get Bruce to relax almost every other rule that wasn’t directly related to safety. Tim and Damian, of all partnerships, had been directing their siblings in what to ask and when, casually pulling the ‘since we can’t reveal our names, can we at least…’ card with brutal efficiency. 
There had been two parties in the Batcave, holiday costumes for the last year, and nine separate team-ups with some of the greyer villains. Not to mention the Gopher Incident and the mini-golf debacle. Dick had stood on the manor grounds after that one, lazily twirling a putter he’d picked up after walking into the mess side by side with Bruce (after saving him from a four hour Board Meeting) and said that Bruce now folded as reliably as a bat sought the dark. 
Alfred had actually agreed. Aloud. 
Bruce sighed. He’d fold soon enough on the names, too. His kids were good and strong and together. They could handle themselves and he’d just have to handle the worry. 
Though not just yet. This nonsense could fuel his arguments for anonymity for at least another two to three weeks. None of his children had the patience for this kind of mess, except maybe Jason who’d like to incite the chaos to greater heights. Or Steph who’d throw food at the heroes while heckling them the entire time. Or Tim who’d record everything for blackmail. 
Maybe he’d better not mention it after all. 
Bruce refocused briefly when he heard his name again, someone trying to point out flaws in his performance that didn’t exist. He knew he had flaws, he knew he made mistakes (his children loved to point them out, at length and at volume), but Bruce had followed the plan. 
Hal was the one who uttered the death blow, which certainly wasn’t a surprise. Nor was the way he blithely continued on as if he hadn’t doomed them all. 
“Look, I just don’t see why we need to take advice on teamwork from a man who dresses up as a Bat and ‘Works Alone.’ Not that anyone besides us would put up with you, so I can’t imagine you’d get much practice.”
Bruce blinked, slowly, and used his considerable training to refrain from pinching the bridge of his nose. He ignored both Diana and Clark arguing against Hal, which was rather sweet of them, to stare at his oldest son. 
Dick had gone still in a way that very few ever pegged as dangerous. Bruce, however, had been convinced by a tiny child on completely calm feet that having a colourful acrobat tailing his shadow across dreary, crime-filled rooftops was a good idea. Bruce understood that a still Nightwing meant he was utterly focused and it was time resort to evasive manoeuvres. 
The rest of Bruce’s children had taken longer to make that connection, what with Dick intentionally hiding behind a smile and a laugh and his role of big brother. Sometimes Bruce hated how much he’d let fall onto Dick shoulders, but then Dick would show up with pizza and movies and always always end those evenings with a hug and a whispered thank you in Bruce’s ear. 
They’d caught on though. Barbara first (she’d always been Dick’s confidant) and then Cass and Jason and all the others. These days a quiet Nightwing spread ripples of concern through the entire Gotham rotation as they tensed with uneasiness and prepared for complete mobilization because their Big Bird was going nowhere alone. 
The Justice League could perhaps be excused for not recognizing the danger in the iron-straight spine of their newest recruit. They hadn’t had near enough exposure to the cheery hero to see beyond the smiles. Though Barry was eyeing the man he’d sponsored with a caution that Bruce was honestly surprised and bit impressed to see. 
Dick began typing into the tablet he’d had in front of him, ostensibly for playback and mission reports. Bruce glanced at his own screen, which stayed blank for for longer than he thought it should have before the message appeared. 
 
Nightwing: Nothing Agent A won’t approve, promise. 
 
Bruce leaned back, getting the attention of a concerned looking Clark which Bruce summarily ignored.
Bruce thought about his butler. He thought about how Alfred’s eyes always darkened when any of his family was insulted. He thought about how the man had been sending Bruce disappointed looks for months now as he put off introducing the League to his children. 
He thought about his children. He thought about how his children had come together and settled over this last year under his guidance and Dick’s care and their own choices to become a more solid family than he could have ever dreamed. A family that could and would protect each other. 
He thought about the Justice League and how Bruce’s children didn’t always listen to him but would have known better to poke a fucking button next to a vat of unidentified liquid in the middle of a villain’s lair. 
Bruce stood, cape flaring out and gaining the attention of everyone in the room almost instantly. 
“I’m going on vacation,” Bruce said. He didn’t think he’d ever seen his teammates look so flabbergasted or Dick so proud. “Maybe I’ll learn something about teamwork while away.”
He certainly would, since he planned on burying himself in his competent children. Though maybe he’d take a bit of time off with Selina somewhere warm and see if he could sneak back as many jewels as she stole.
“Don’t call me for two weeks,” Bruce continued as if one of the silent Justice League members had said anything at all. Dick’s nose wrinkled and Bruce sighed. “Make that four. Try not to burn anything to the ground while I’m gone.”
Hal started sputtering indignantly, but Bruce hadn’t been talking to him. 
Dick only smirked, which wasn’t an agreement. Bruce paused a moment, but decided it wan’t his problem and left with what might have passed as a wink to Diana and Clark. They had tried to defend him after all, so maybe deserved a little bit of warning.

They started small. Partly because escalation was a sound battle strategy but mostly because they were petty little shits. Petty little shits with four whole weeks. 
They started by stealing all the spoons. Well, Cass stole all the spoons, because she was a damn ghost and the least likely to be distracted with the entire Batfamily arguing on the comms about the definition of ‘spoon.’ She was clearly still listening, however, since she also grabbed soup ladles, measuring cups (both science and kitchen), wooden stirring spoons, two gardening spades, and two large cleaning buckets to carrying everything. 
She was frowning when she came back, that particular expression that Dick knew was part genuine disappointment and part pout. 
“Too easy,” Cass said as she placed the buckets on the table with an audible thump that really expressed her irritation.
“I completely agree.” Babs frowned from the Batcomputer that she and Tim had taken shared custody over as soon as Bruce had left the manor. The man had tried to use his Justice League vacation to catch up on Gotham work for all of an hour before he caved to Alfred’s frosty glare and the combined eyes of Tim and Damian. 
Dick had maybe deserved the glare Bruce had sent his way as a laughing Selena tugged him to the car, but only maybe. His brothers had really added their own flare to the Baby Bird Eyes of Dick’s youth, so he would argue that he was no longer responsible. But Bruce was gone so couldn’t actually assign blame anyways. 
Babs pulled up a still frame from the surveillance footage of Black Bat casually sitting on top of cabinet, one leg dangling, as Green Lantern and Hawkgirl walked down the hallway. 
Dick scratched the back of his head. “They’re in a safe place. They know they’re secure so are relaxing their guard.” 
At the incredulous looks his family was sending, Dick held up both palms. “Hey, none of that now. Didn’t say it was excusable. My Titans would be running drills for weeks, remember? Just want to put out a little context and keep in mind the fact that these people are highly trained. And that we’re literally poking them into paranoia with a sharp, bat-shaped stick so we can’t expect this behaviour the whole way through.”
“Fair enough,” Tim scowled as he typed. “But it’s still going in the report.”
“Course, Baby Bird.” Dick leaned on the back of Tim’s chair. “How’s the cybersecurity?”
Tim and Babs scoffed as one, Damian looking over from where he and Duke were paying way too close attention to something Jay was doing with wires. Damian looked just slightly confused at how similar their sound was to his trademark noise. No one else noticed the reaction, however, so Dick vowed to keep it to himself. For now.
“Abysmal.” Babs huffed again, crossing her arms to glare at the screen that held security from all across the Watchtower. “I mean, I helped Bruce set a lot of this up, so it’s not like it was going to be particularly challenging for me to get into, but I haven’t been involved in maintaining the systems and it shows.”
“Part of Bruce’s over-protective paranoia,” Tim explained rather unnecessarily, but slightly petulantly. Dick knew the boy had permanent routes into the Justice League databases but had mostly, reluctantly, also left the security alone. 
Babs started typing again. “I know Cyborg at least is better than this.”
“Cyborg isn’t allowed that deep into the systems yet. Technically all us newbies are still on probation.”
Babs looked over her glasses at him. “That’s both fair and an extreme waste of resources.”
“We are ready for Stage Two,” Damian announced before Dick could respond. 
“No,” Dick told Damian, Duke, and Jason, none of them even attempting to hide the small detonation device they’d been working on. “That’s like, Stage Six. At the earliest. And I know you all know that; you were part of the planning and the briefing.”
“Tt.”
“Fine, Dickiebird. Ruin our fun. Come on, Demon Brat, just means more time for building.”
Duke didn’t follow Jason as the man walked away. Instead he tilted his head. “So when exactly is Stage Two starting?”
There was a cackle and all heads turned back to the screens, Cass offering Dick a handful of popcorn from the bowl she’d somehow produced.
“Do I want to know why you had that much purple spray paint on hand?” Tim asked, sighing at the screen Duke was now staring at with hands on his hips.
“Probably not, Baby Bird,” Dick lied as he settled on the arm of his brother’s chair to watch Spoiler creep through the vents he’d extensively mapped within a week of gaining probationary access to the Watchtower. “Probably not.”
Spoiler spray painted all the weapons in the Tower purple for Stage Two. She started in the armoury only to use the fuss of everyone being drawn to the armoury by the newly purple weapons to hit what was left in the training rooms. She didn’t get everything, leaving weapons that would be damaged permanently by the paint or might react badly to the chemicals (there were some odd alien or magic things in the Tower), but otherwise was very thorough.
And Dick and Steph had been very thorough with the paint itself. It was Batpaint. It was not coming out without a particular mixture that the Flash could maybe synthesize, except for the part where he was an ally and wouldn’t dare. 
Steph also hit the things that were only weapons to a Bat. She found a couple of umbrellas. Replaced the kitchen pans with specialty purple ones that wouldn’t contaminate food. Painted a couple of small, decorative statues. Managed to paint the entirety of a bookcase (while leaving all objects on said bookcase untouched) in honour of the shelving unit Damian had managed to topple onto drug kingpin last month. 
She also placed her purple cactus Stevie on the kitchen counter under Aquaman’s snacks. Dick had given her that cactus for Christmas, and was very happy to see it weaponized for a good cause. Tim had thought the force-field enabled pot a bit overkill, but Dick had known it would come in handy.
Really, Steph had been Dick’s Batgirl, in the awful time when he’d worn the Batman cowl. The Batfamily had no excuse not to realize just how frequently he and Steph were in perfectly coordinated cahoots. The only one who had picked up on their particular, patient brand of chaos was Damian (their Robin), and he was In On It half the time. 
The fact that the paint was not being used for the original intended purpose was a little disappointing, but he and Steph agreed that needs must. Besides, another month of false-security where Bruce’s beloved Batmobile remained untouched would only be to their benefit. 
Timing had to perfect for revenge, after all.

The next few days or so were calmer, or so they seemed. Duke had suggested an early lull to further make things seem like just a couple of small pranks and allow for one on one targeting. He had been abashed when Cass had patted him on the head, but pleased with the general approval of the family. His psychological warfare training had clearly been progressing smoothly. 
Cass took Green Lantern for her part in the one on one targeting, hiding any remote from his view but always returning it when someone else appeared and Hal asked. Wonder Woman’s expression when she’d pointed to the remote for the monitors sitting on the nearby table was a thing of beauty. 
Duke himself was responsible for using his illusion powers to periodically move Steph’s cactus in a strategic manner. He’d chosen Aquaman as his target to Steph’s approval.
Jason had methodically switched all the books on the Watchtower to poetry volumes and Shakespeare. Martian Manhunter was more bemused than anything, but seemed to actually enjoyed the volumes and go on a hunt for the others. Green Arrow was a different story, particularly when technology started beeping at him and the physical instruction manuals were no longer to be found.
Tim signed Hawkgirl up for a mailing list about cookware, and then proceeded to find other lists for other heroes that referenced conversations that he shouldn’t have had access to in the first place. 
Damian had created an intel report focused on the fictional Rancher King’s plan to steal all the world’s cows. It was a thing of beauty, full of details and just enough plausibility that Shazam couldn’t quite dismiss it off hand and pulled in Flash and Black Canary. 
Steph and Babs had loved this particular plan so much that Steph was on page twenty four of the Rancher King’s manifesto and Damian and Dick were currently on the Batplane to check out a recently decommissioned farm warehouse (the Riddler had recently tried a plan involving the international stage, animal puns, and way too many eggs) in order to repurpose it as the Rancher King’s lair.
They wouldn’t take the Justice League’s attention from actual cases, naturally, but it had been a fairly calm week and the ‘case’ would build slowly. Hints would be dropped at appropriate (non-life-threatening) times to allude to the Rancher King’s unfortunate past as a mistreated farm hand after his tragic accident in a lab that specialized in shrinking technology. 
They were running a little wild, but really, they’d seen stranger things. Also, Dick was very glad that none of his family were really inclined to jump into the whole costumed villainy thing, Jay’s anti-hero declarations aside. Steph’s fake manifesto was very impassioned and Tim had a lot of ideas on how one might reasonably steal all the world’s cows, starting in the US.
Dick would be concerned, but he was too busy being proud.
Damian came to sit on the arm of Dick’s chair and Dick switched everything over to autopilot; they still had a good thirty minutes before they arrived. He waited patiently, absently pretending to check different instruments until Damian found whatever words he needed. 
“Is it my fault?”
Dick didn’t actually know what his baby brother was talking about so he bit back the desire to promise that ‘it’ wasn’t. He loved Damian with all his heart but knew well the kid was a bit of a hellion who, through no fault of his own, sometimes needed the ‘assassin ways of doing things are not the only or even the best ways of doing things’ conversation.
“Is what your fault, Baby Bat?”
“Father’s lockdown on identities. I am the youngest. It would be logical to assume that if I was not involved the order would have been removed long ago.”
Dick leaned back, head thumping lightly into the chair. “No, Damian, it’s not you fault.” Before Damian could scoff, Dick nudged the boys shoulder and wrapped a hand around the kid’s knee, making him just a bit more secure on his perch. “Duke is newer than you, though not younger, and without your extensive training. The lockdown order was because we were young as a family, and so were the various Superhero teams. And because B is paranoid.”
Dick raised a hand and traced it along Dami’s cheekbone, a move that the kid wouldn’t have accepted a year ago and probably still wouldn’t accept from anyone else. “We weren’t ready, Baby Bat. Not with everything that’s happened in Gotham and the family in the last few years. But we are now. We know exactly how we’ll react when one of us is in trouble and its by pulling together. We trust our allies and our training and each other and it’s time now. Despite the way B’s love is making him scared.”
Damian leaned in, slight relief lacing his spine. Dick couldn’t help but think this would be good for them all and not just because of the increased social connections and security to their friendships. They were all comfortable in the shadows, in secrecy, but there was something weighty in being acknowledged. It wasn’t just his Baby Bat that could use another, more public claim that he belonged. That he was theirs.
Dick was going to tell everyone how proud of his family he was. He had a list. There were photos attached. It was maybe more of document or a report. In Power Point. With animations.
Regardless, he had so much bragging to do.
“And Father will agree?”
Dick didn’t say that he was pretty sure Bruce already had. While he was irritatingly good at ignoring comments aimed his way because Batman didn’t care and Brucie didn’t notice, he was also irritatingly good at reading Dick. Bruce knew what giving Dick, much less the entire family, free reign actually meant. 
With a smile, Dick wrapped his arms around Damian’s waist, ignoring the slight squawk and what were only token protests. “Course he will. That’s Robin’s job, isn’t it? To pull Bruce into the light even when the shadows are his own fears?”
Damian looked at Dick for a long moment, face still and intent, before he scoffed. “And to hurt those who hurt him.”
Dick laughed. 
His brother wasn’t wrong, after all.

Dick’s gloved fingers flexed in Jay’s jacket and the younger man reached up to cover them. 
“I get B’s secrecy policy. I even agreed with it, mostly, when I wasn’t being an idiot teenager. But, it’s been a hard few years.” Dick lowered his head again, right over his baby brother’s (beating, not stopped) heart. “A really hard few years. We’ve come so far, Little Wing. So far. I’m just so so proud of us. And, I don’t- I want people to know.”
Jason shifted slightly as Dick breathed, his hands pressing into Dick as if bracing him.
“When the Joker kidnapped Robin,” Jason started slowly, tensing along with Dick though neither moved away, “we were patrolling together. I remember hearing Bruce’s voice on the comms, but not his words. There was a lot of green in my vision, but I still saw you, your expression. Dick laughed, probably a bit wetly.
“Yeah,” Jason agreed, definitely a bit gruffly. “And sure, B’s plan for the secret army to protect the kids with the element of surprise was fine, but I’m for something a bit more direct. We’ll let the world know what Gotham already does.”

Dick had watched is family grow and take the skies and try to do nothing more or less than help. Dick had taken a long look at all the strays his father had started trying to care for, to save, and said okay. Had said alright. Had said mine. 
The Batkids knew what that meant, now. Bruce had always known, even if he’d briefly forgotten, because Bruce had let a child call himself Batman’s partner and understood that for all the ways it wasn’t true, there was more that one way it was. 
“Big Bird not alone, either.” Cass buried her face in Dick’s hair.
“Fuck no,” Jay said. “I ain’t letting you fuck shit up on your own. Time to punch all those shitheads in the face.”
Dick laughed again. This time the sound was warm and soft and bladed around the edges.

Batman felt this was a lot for Hood to be dealing with, so threw a series of Batarangs at Green Arrow, who split his attention from Hood to face Batman. This was a mistake, since he completely missed Spoiler creeping up behind him in order to whack him in the arm with a large purple frying pan. 
Green Arrow went down to one knee at the force of the blow and Batman slid forward into the space to bind him. Green Arrow glared at Batman, frown only growing as Spoiler yanked his quiver off his back and danced away after a quick sideways hug for Batman.
“What the fuck are you doing?” Green Arrow asked. 
“Winning,” Batman replied. 
He watched Spoiler kick Black Canary in the stomach, Red Robin attacking from behind after switching spots with Signal. Signal and Hood were wrapping up the fight with the Flashes, using Signal’s powers to manoeuvre both speedsters into the optimal position for Hood’s tranquilizers. Kid Flash was already down, cuffed, and hurling playful insults at Nightwing. 
Nightwing and Robin were dancing. 
The two of them were taking on Hawkgirl and flipping around each other so much that Hawkgirl was getting dizzy, swearing up a storm and demanding they stay fucking still. Batman could have told her that Nightwing didn’t do still. 
Wonder Girl came to Hawkgirl’s rescue and Nightwing ducked down so Robin could spring off his back, gaining height for a spectacular barrage of Birdarangs. Robin landed amidst a pink smoke bomb thrown by Nightwing and disarmed Hawkgirl of her mace which was sent flying into Spoiler’s waiting clutches. Nightwing took the moment to signal for Black Bat to take over for him, since he was intentionally avoiding fighting any of the Titans as they were already highly familiar with is abilities.
This probably also explained why Raven was already off to the side, bearing a cheap name-tag style sticker that read ‘Out’ in blue marker on her cloak. She looked quiet content to sit and watch. Cyborg was ignoring everything to type madly at a computer. Batman knew the stance of a techie losing a battle with Oracle well. 
Batman barely had time to check his own takedowns of Aquaman and Green Arrow and confirm that one of his children had attached an ‘Out’ sticker to both their foreheads, before he spun and caught Wonder Woman’s sword on his gauntlet. 
“Your children are marvellous,” she told him, a wide grin on her face.
He let himself smile back, amused at the increased glee on Wonder Woman’s face. “I know.”
He ducked, and Wonder Woman started, just slightly, which unbalanced her when she ducked a moment later to doge Nightwing’s kick. Nightwing crouched for just a moment, back pressed into Batman’s shin, grinning wildly. Batman placed one heavy palm on his son’s messy hair and then they moved.
Back and forth, sideways and zigzag, he and Nightwing pressed ever forward in a pattern they’d been perfecting for years. They’d worked for this smoothness, for this ability just to know where the other would be. They’d worked to get it back after harsh words and changing styles had damaged what once had been instinctive. 
Batman was the strong arm, the brute and ruthless force. Nightwing was the precision weapon, the sharp and relentless edge. They backed Wonder Woman up, step by step, until she stood almost back to back with Superman.
Superman was holding Red Hood up by the scrub of his coat, letting him dangle there with crossed arms. Clearly, the man didn’t quite know what to do with Hood now that he was caught. This wasn’t exactly an uncommon experience with Hood.
Nightwing, however, pivoted off Batman’s back (exactly as Damian had done his, and Bruce hadn’t teared up the first time he’d seen them complete that manoeuvre, Tim and his photography were lying) to leap over Wonder Woman’s head, land neatly on Superman’s shoulders, and shove Kryptonite in his face. 
Superman staggered, which released Hood just enough for the man to slip cuffs out of his coat and onto Superman’s wrists. There was an ‘Out’ tag in blue and red marker on the cuffs with a note underneath saying ‘We both know these could have been laced with Kryptonite; sit the fuck down.’
Wonder Woman continued her turn to track Nightwing and shifted in a move meant to free Superman. She halted half way when Black Bat tapped her on the shoulder and pointed to the ‘Out’ sticker Black Bat had placed on her skirt during Nightwing’s showy move.
With a laugh, Wonder Woman sat, dragging a bemused Superman down with her. 
Batman turned to survey the rest of the chaos, and saw that it had mostly wrapped up. Martian Manhunter was also sitting calmly, tag on his cloak and smile on his face. Shazam was wrapped in some sort of jelly substance, sticker on his cheek. Black Canary was sitting against a wall, meta cuffs on her wrist and sticker on her boot.
Red Arrow and Wonder Girl were arguing with each other as Robin stuck a sticker to each of the arms, right over the reinforced rope that tied the two together. Aqualad had a gag over his mouth with an ‘Out’ tag hanging off it and was sitting at his mentor’s feet and patting him on the leg in what was either meant to be a comforting or condescending manner. 
“Well, I think that wraps things up nicely, don’t you?” Nightwing asked, coming to stand at Batman’s side. 
Batman eyed his son speculatively and waited. Spoiler dropped down from the ceiling, sack full of now purple weaponry clanking to the floor and drawing the attention of all the heroes. Except for Green Lantern, who Hood dropped next to the sack. 
“Now we’re wrapped up,” Red Robin said as he approached with Black Bat and Signal trailing him. 
Batman sighed. 
“What. The. Fuck.” Green Lantern glared at them all, but mostly Batman. 
“Teamwork exercises.” Nightwing sang at him. 
“Let us go, you fucking nightmares.”
Seven domino masks turned to look at Batman. Bruce crossed his arms because they clearly didn’t need him to defend them. “You are nightmares.” 
There were various shrugs and grins, because they were self-aware nightmares and proud of the fact.
Dick leaned forward. “Not until you admit we’ve won.”
Green Lantern grew red in the face as he drew breath to shout something that would be more effective if he wasn’t tied up with something that looked like a child’s yellow skipping rope. It wasn’t, but one of Bruce’s children had tied tassels to it for the express purpose of pissing Green Lantern off. 
“Of course!” Wonder Woman beat Green Lantern to speaking. “We certainly concede victory. Your teamwork was most excellent.”
“Agreed,” said Superman who raised his cuffed hands in a silent question. It took Bruce a bare moment to realize that all his kids were looking at him again, even Nightwing. 
“You’ve had your fun. Release them.” Bruce was rather proud that he didn’t sigh or pinch the bridge of his nose. Or smile.
“Do we have to?” Muttered Damian, but Cass and Tim were already setting the League members that needed freeing go, Stephanie following behind to hand out now purple weaponry to their respective owners. 
Wonder Woman and Superman approached, apparently quite happy to go with the tacit agreement that Green Lantern would be released last. 
“I have never seen you fight quite like that, Batman,” said Diana, “not once over our many years of friendship.”
“Well, I’ve been fighting with him even longer than that,” Dick said from Bruce’s elbow.
“What?!” Both Flashes popped up at their sides, heralding the crowding of everyone else. 
“How the heck do you all know each other.” Hawkgirl was swinging her mace as she spoke, seemingly not too upset at it being purple.
“Please tell me you noticed the bats.” Tim was pinching his nose. “At least four of us literally have bats emblazoned across our chests. Please tell me one of you noticed that.”
“I did,” said Diana, slightly smug. 
Clark nudged her in the side with his elbow. “Hey, I knew first.”
“Only cause I gave it to you, Uncle Supes,” Dick said rather fondly. 
“Smiling Batman,” Barry muttered at Dick’s expression, apparently ignoring the uncle part completely. 
“Called it!” Wally shouted, beaming as he nudged his own uncle in the ribs.
“Alright over there, Flashes?” Dick asked. 
“I know you’re aware that your generation calls you the smiling Batman,” Bruce told his son, quite happy to ignore the way Clark was practically glowing at being called an uncle.
Dick smiled up at him. “Yup! Spent like three months trying to decide what to do if they confronted me about it.”
Tim leaned around Jason. “You were going to gaslight them, right? Deny everything like you were utterly confused about what ever led them to that connection?”
“Well, yeah. Much more fun. But they all kept it to whispers behind my back. Like hearing the whispers behind your back wasn’t Day One of Dad’s Bat Training.”
Bruce frowned because that was not Day One of Bat Training.
“Don’t be stupid, Dickface. That’s Week Six.”
“Thank you, Jason,” Bruce said, because Jason wasn’t wrong. 
“Jason!?” Bruce tilted his head as he realized several of his children’s voices had been in that mix. 
“Yes? I thought that was the second part of this. Weren’t you making it impossible to hide you existence so you could reveal your identities?”
“Yup.” Nightwing bounced forward, draping himself over Bruce’s back. “Hiding made sense when we were still vulnerable and young, but we’re in a good place B. Time to step out of the shadows, just a bit.”
Bruce hummed. But, well, Dick had always been pulling him out of the shadows. 
He turned to the Justice League, absently noting both speedsters practically vibrating and Clark and Diana both smiling at him with a warm softness that seemed all the brighter for the vernal shock the others were still operating under. 
“Dad’s Bat Training. Batman is a father. He has children.” Oliver said to Dinah in what was probably supped to be a whisper. He turned to Roy. “Wait, please tell me you didn’t know about this?”
“Nope.” Roy said, glaring at an unrepentant Dick
“This is my oldest,” Bruce started, ignoring them all, “Dick Grayson. He’s an acrobatic barnacle.” 
Jason and Tim both snorted, the older outright cackling, but Bruce could feel his oldest beam as he tightened his arms. 
“B adopted me when I was a kid after I watched my birth parents die. I started young, but B saved me. And I saved him.”
“Robin.” All heads turned to a soft-eyed Wonder Woman who was looked between Nightwing and Damian with the R on his chest. “We thought he was a myth, a false legend. Particularly when a Robin appeared with the Titans and denied all connection to Gotham. But he was your son.” 
“He was. The League was still new and I didn’t trust you yet. Not with him.”
“Robin became a mantle.” Dick smile, warmth genuine and not bladed as it had been for the last few weeks. “Jay had it for a while, then Tim, Steph, and now Damian.”
“I only had it for coverage purposes!” Steph piped up.
“Still counts,” everyone else said, excepting Damian.
Damian crossed his arms. “Tt. You should take pride in your part of the esteemed legacy of Robin.”
Dick let out a coo that made several of the heroes, probably ones he’d kicked in the head, flinch. He released Bruce in order to pounce on Damian with a hug the boy might have escaped if it wasn’t for Steph joining in. 
Bruce sighed, but there was a fondness there that he knew Diana at least had caught. “Jason Todd, known as Red Hood, is my third eldest, but the second adopted.”
“I stole the tires off the Batmobile,” Jason told the room with a smirk as he removed his hood and mask.
“Timothy Drake, known as Red Robin, discovered our identities and was adopted shortly after.”
“We had to deal with his parents first!” Chirped Dick to general alarm. 
Tim side-eyed his brother before taking off his own mask and addressing the assembled heroes. “I helped. They just signed over custody. Not like they really cared one way or another.” 
Jason ruffled his hair and Duke patted him on the arm. 
“Damian,” Bruce continued, “the current Robin, is both an Al Ghul and a Wayne. He’s the youngest and the only one biologically mine.”
“The Blood Son!” Every single one of his children chorused with varying tones. Damian scoffed but didn’t throw off Dick or Steph, even as Dick gently peeled away the boy’s domino. 
“Stephanie Brown, currently known as Spoiler, isn’t legally mine-“
“Just spiritually and financially!” The girl thew in.
“-and was an independent vigilante until Tim befriended her and brought her into the family.”
“No take backs.” Tim and Dick agreed with a high-five over a giggling Steph’s head. 
“Duke Thomas, known as the Signal, is our newest addition. He’s the only exception to the no metas in Gotham rule.”
“Nice to meet you,” Duke told the Justice League, who looked a little awed at his manners. Duke must have seen that however, because he promptly ruined it after removing his mask. “I’m new, but I promise my initiation was very thorough.” 
This time Dick and Jason exchanged grins that had Garth taking a step behind a flabbergasted Arthur.
There was a moment of silence before Diana grinned. “And the last?”
Heads started turning as most of them realized there had been another. Cass dropped down from the ceiling next to Bruce, completely silent, startling a few others into retreating steps. 
“Cassandra Cain, known as Black Bat. She’s my second eldest.”
Cass patted his cheek before going to lean on Tim. 
“But,” Bruce cut off a grinning Clark, “the last is actually Oracle, formally Batgirl.”
“Wait,” Barry said. “I thought Signal was the only other meta. Is Oracle invisible?”
“I’m not,” Barbara’s voice came clearly through the speaker system. “Barbara Gordon, at your service.”
“She’s our tech goddess and you should always do as she says,” Tim told the League earnestly. 
“Hello, Oracle,” chorused every Titan in the room to the amusement of a grinning Nightwing. 
“Titans,” she acknowledged.
Dick shrugged as the League turned to him. “Babs and I are best friends and the original Bats. She’s never physically met the Titans but I wasn’t about to lead a team she wasn’t part of.”
“Couldn’t if you tried, Boy Blunder.”
“True,” Dick agreed happily. 
“So all this was to fucking introduce yourselves? To get Daddy Bats to spill your names to your friends?” Hal asked, not sounding particularly pleased as a glob of paint rolled off his suit and puddled onto the floor. He had still not been handed back his ring and Bruce wasn’t even sure which child had it. Jason wasn’t currently smug enough to still have it in his possession. 
Hal didn’t notice each of the kids tense, but the other heroes certainly did.
“No,” Cass said.
“This was because you insulted Batman,” Tim continued.
“And that’s our job.” Jason leaned onto Tim’s shoulder.
Dick stepped forward, the others fanning out loosely behind him, not quite threatening but explicitly supportive. 
“You fucked up,” he told the Justice League. “You messed up a mission and instead of talking about it like adults, or even like the teenagers I’ve trained, you took it out on one of your senior members. One of your friends.”
There was shifting feet and downward glances.
Dick stepped forward again and Bruce was absently impressed that Hal didn’t step back. 
“Batman is abrasive, authoritarian, reticent, secretive, and kind. He’s given more to this team than you can possibly understand and I sat there and watched you ignore his input, blame him for following a plan you all agreed upon, and insult his every effort. Batman has worked with partners before the Justice League took down it’s first mugger, and, though I’m not sure you caught this with your selective hearing, he adopted a bunch of baby vigilantes to make sure we were safe and prepared and never alone.”
Nightwing took another step forward, his demeanour still and sharp even as he didn’t reach for a weapon. Not that he had to, what with six highly-trained and possibly trigger-happy siblings at his back. 
“No, Green Lantern. This wasn’t an introduction, it was a threat. Get your act together or we’re taking him back.”
Nightwing stared at Hal for a long moment, making sure that the man had nothing to say. When Dick clapped his hands together and tossed Hal’s ring back, three different heroes jumped, to the snickers of the Batfamily and sympathetic looks of the Titans.
“Not that we want that outcome. We’re just so happy that B has friends!”
Bruce was too busy staring to refute that comment with his usual disdain. His children had just threatened, effectively, the entire Justice League. He was slightly put out but also very proud. 
Tim was nodding. “Also. Agent A has prepared cookies, if anyone want to join us at the Manor.”
“And you do,” Dick told the Titans, “because those are the cookies that you lot once literally destroyed a floor of the Tower over.”
“Agent A?” J’onn asked, coming closer from where he’d, quite intelligently, been lurking around the edges. “Is there another child?”
That actually made each of his children blink for a moment, before bursting out into various chuckles and guffaws. Even Damian was smirking. 
“Agent A is my father,” Bruce explained.
“We would be honoured to meet you father.” Diana clapped Bruce on his shoulder before linking their arms. “I look forward to seeing your home and learning more about your wondrous children.”
“Wait a fucking second!” Oliver yelled, Dinah’s hand on his arm. All heads turned to him and he pointed at Bruce. “Bruce Wayne is Batman?!” 
“Oh my god, you absolute Dickhead,” muttered Roy who’d actually met all the Waynes at one gala or another.
“Huh,” Dick smiled as his siblings fell into even deeper laughter. “Guess we forgot that part.”
Bruce sighed again, but he also smiled as he removed the cowl.
